Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk valgrind
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: valgrind bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The valgrind packages provide the Valgrind programming tool that helps detect memory-management problems in programs. Valgrind is used for debugging memory, detecting memory leaks, and profiling. The valgrind packages have been upgraded to upstream version 3.10.0, which provides a number of bug fixes and enhancements over the previous version. The important fixes and enhancements include: Support for the 64-bit ARM Architecture (AArch64 ARMv8) and for the little-endian variant of IBM Power Systems have been added. The --db-attach option is now deprecated and will be removed in the next feature valgrind packages release. The built-in Valgrind gdbserver capabilities, see the --vgdb options, are superior and should be used instead. Error messages that include stack traces can now show inline function calls if the DWARF debug information format is available. These can also be used in suppressions. Error messages concerning dubious arguments (for example, to malloc or calloc) now include a stack trace and can be used in suppressions. The C++ demangler has been updated for better C++11 support. The Valgrind gdbserver functionality now supports display of thread local variables and storage (__thread). Three new monitor commands have been added to Valgrind: "v.info location [address]" to show more information about an address, "v.info stats" to show various Valgrind core and tool statistics, and "v.set hostvisibility", which allows Valgrind gdbserver to provide access to Valgrind internal host status and memory. There is also a new valgrind command line option, "--vgdb-stop-at=[event1],[event2],...", which allows the user to ask the Valgrind gdbserver to stop at the start of program execution, at the end of the program execution, and when valgrind aborts on internal errors. In the Valgrind memcheck tool, the client code can now selectively disable and re-enable reporting of invalid address errors in specific ranges using new client requests. In addition, more accurate checking of system call parameters that use uninitialized fields in structures has been added. Finally, it is now possible to disable the mismatched checking of memory deallocation using the "free" function via the new "--show-mismatched-frees=no|yes" flag, with the default value remaining "yes". In the Valgrind helgrind tool, more information about race conditions and locks is now shown in error messages as the new Valgrind gdbserver monitor command gives the list of locks, their location, and their status. (BZ#1097769) This update also fixes the following bug: Previously, programs that were explicitly compiled against the valgrind.h header file to include Valgrind client requests for 32-bit PowerPC binaries (ppc32), but not 64-bit PowerPC binaries (ppc64), could unexpectedly clobber a register (r0) causing subtle bugs. The latest rebase of the valgrind packages (3.10.0) fixes the bug in the client request magic instruction sequence for ppc32. Code needs to be recompiled for ppc32 against the new valgrind.h header file to fix the bug. Code that has not been rebuilt might contain the bug, which Valgrind now detects and returns a warning message. (BZ#1141166) Users of valgrind are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
